A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.

An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A polynomial is defined as a formal sum with coefficients in a field or ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand the coefficients in the polynomial.
The units of a ring are defined as the multiplicatively invertible elements of the ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand its units.
The sum of ideals is defined for ideals in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand the sum of its ideals.
A ring automorphism is an isomorphism from a ring to itself. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand its automorphisms.

An irreducible polynomial is defined as a polynomial that cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial must be defined to understand irreducible polynomials.

An irreducible polynomial is defined as a polynomial that cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand irreducible polynomials.
A free A-module is defined as an A-module with a basis. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand free modules.
An algebra over a ring is defined as a ring homomorphism from one ring to another. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand algebras over rings.
The prime subfield of a finite field is the smallest subfield contained within the field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand its prime subfield.
A group action is defined as a map from the Cartesian product of a group and a set to the set. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand group actions.
A transposition is defined as a 2-cycle. Therefore, the concept of a cycle must be defined to understand transpositions.
